Tweet text: Nobody can watch into my wallet today and follow what i use my cash for.What's my garantie that it stays that way with a digital wallet ?

and they would require some form of ID in order to prevent financial crime or fraud. Your privacy would still be protected by data privacy regulations and your personal data would not be shared with the Bank or the government. 3/3

You would access the digital pound through a virtual wallet and you would have to share some personal data with your wallet provider. This is because you would have a commercial relationship with your provider 2/3
Hi
column3: the Bank of England and the government would not collect any of your personal data and wouldn't be able to see how you spent your money. 1/3

Tweet text: it would be good if you removed the PROMISE TO PAY from your notes because you pay NOTHING.
This phrase dates from long ago when our notes represented deposits of gold. The value of the pound hasn't been linked to gold for many years
Tweet date;: so the meaning of the promise to pay has changed. You can only exchange notes for other Bank of England notes of the same face value.
